Whale Watching in Mexico: Complete Seasonal Guide

Gray Whales, Humpbacks & Whale Sharks—Where and When to See Them

Last updated: January 2025

Mexico offers some of the world's most incredible whale encounters. Gray whales travel 5,000 miles to birth their calves in Baja's warm lagoons—and actively approach boats for interaction. Humpbacks perform acrobatic displays off Puerto Vallarta and Los Cabos. Whale sharks—the ocean's gentle giants—gather in massive congregations near Holbox and La Paz. This guide covers every species, location, and season.

In This Guide

  • Quick Season Overview
  • Gray Whales in Baja California
  • Humpback Whales
  • Whale Sharks
  • Other Whale Species
  • Best Locations Ranked
  • Planning Your Trip
  • What to Expect on Tours
  • Responsible Whale Watching
  • Photography Tips
  • Combining with Other Activities

Quick Season Overview

{<strong>When to See What:</strong></p><p>| Species | Location | Peak Season | |---------|----------|-------------| | Gray Whales | Baja lagoons | January-March | | Humpback Whales | Puerto Vallarta | December-March | | Humpback Whales | Los Cabos | January-March | | Whale Sharks | Holbox | June-September | | Whale Sharks | La Paz | October-April | | Blue Whales | Sea of Cortez | February-March | | Orcas | Sea of Cortez | May-June |</p><p><strong>Best Overall Months:</strong></p><ul><li><strong>February</strong>: Gray whales peak + humpbacks active + whale sharks in La Paz</p><ul><li><strong>July-August</strong>: Whale sharks peak at Holbox</p><ul><li><strong>January</strong>: Humpbacks most active at Puerto Vallarta</p><p><strong>Plan Ahead:</strong> Peak whale watching requires advance booking. Gray whale lagoon trips sell out months ahead. Popular humpback tours fill up weeks in advance.}

Gray Whales in Baja California

{<strong>The World's Friendliest Whales</strong></p><p>Gray whales make the longest migration of any mammal—5,000+ miles from Alaska to Baja California's warm lagoons to give birth and nurse their calves. Remarkably, they often approach boats and allow (even seek) human touch.</p><p><strong>Primary Locations:</strong></p><p><strong>Laguna Ojo de Liebre (Scammon's Lagoon)</strong></p><ul><li>Near Guerrero Negro, Baja California Sur</p><ul><li>Largest concentration of gray whales</p><ul><li>Most accessible lagoon</p><ul><li>3-4 hour tours</p><p><strong>Laguna San Ignacio</strong></p><ul><li>More remote, more intimate</p><ul><li>Famous for "friendly" whale behavior</p><ul><li>Multi-day camps available</p><ul><li>Requires more planning</p><p><strong>Bahía Magdalena (Mag Bay)</strong></p><ul><li>Southern Baja</p><ul><li>Less touristy</p><ul><li>Good for whale watching + fishing combo</p><ul><li>Accessible from La Paz</p><p><strong>Season:</strong></p><ul><li>Whales arrive: Mid-December</p><ul><li>Peak: February</p><ul><li>Whales depart: Late March/April</p><ul><li>Best single month: February</p><p><strong>The Experience:</strong> Small boats (pangas) take you into the lagoons where mothers and calves swim. "Friendly" whales approach boats, surfacing beside you. Some allow touching—an unforgettable moment. Calves are especially curious.</p><p><strong>Typical Tour:</strong></p><ul><li>Duration: 3-4 hours on water</p><ul><li>Cost: $60-100 per person</p><ul><li>Multi-day camps: $200-400/day all-inclusive</p><ul><li>Book 2-3 months ahead for peak dates}

Humpback Whales

{<strong>Acrobatic Giants of the Pacific</strong></p><p>Humpback whales migrate from Alaska to Mexico's Pacific coast to breed and birth. They're famous for spectacular breaches, tail slaps, and haunting songs.</p><p><strong>Puerto Vallarta / Banderas Bay:</strong></p><p>Banderas Bay is one of the world's best humpback destinations—whales come close to shore and numbers are high.</p><p><strong>Season:</strong> December - March <strong>Peak:</strong> January - February <strong>Numbers:</strong> 300-500 whales annually <strong>Best Tours:</strong> Whale watching from Puerto Vallarta or Punta Mita</p><p><strong>What You'll See:</strong></p><ul><li>Breaching (full body leaps)</p><ul><li>Tail slapping</p><ul><li>Spy hopping</p><ul><li>Mother-calf pairs</p><ul><li>Competitive groups (males chasing females)</p><ul><li>Sometimes underwater singing (hydrophone)</p><p><strong>Tour Options:</strong></p><ul><li>Group boat tour: $80-150/person</p><ul><li>Private charter: $400-800</p><ul><li>Duration: 3-4 hours</p><ul><li>Departure: 8-9am typically</p><p>---</p><p><strong>Los Cabos:</strong></p><p>The corridor between Cabo San Lucas and San José del Cabo offers excellent humpback viewing with dramatic rocky backdrops.</p><p><strong>Season:</strong> January - March <strong>Peak:</strong> February <strong>Viewing:</strong> From boats or even shore <strong>Unique:</strong> Whales visible from many resorts</p><p><strong>Tour Options:</strong></p><ul><li>Combined with El Arco visit</p><ul><li>Small boats for closer access</p><ul><li>Luxury yacht options</p><ul><li>Cost: $100-200/person group, $500+ private}

Whale Sharks

{<strong>Swimming with Gentle Giants</strong></p><p>Whale sharks are the world's largest fish—up to 40 feet long—yet they eat only plankton and are completely harmless. Swimming alongside them is a bucket-list experience.</p><p><strong>Holbox Island (Caribbean):</strong></p><p>The Caribbean's largest whale shark aggregation gathers near Holbox and Isla Contoy during summer months.</p><p><strong>Season:</strong> June - September <strong>Peak:</strong> July - August <strong>Numbers:</strong> 100-400+ whale sharks <strong>Access:</strong> Day trips from Holbox or Cancún</p><p><strong>The Experience:</strong></p><ul><li>Boats locate whale shark groups</p><ul><li>Snorkel alongside them in open water</p><ul><li>Two people per guide in water at a time</p><ul><li>Multiple encounters per trip</p><ul><li>Water is warm and visibility good</p><p><strong>Tour Details:</strong></p><ul><li>From Holbox: $125-175/person</p><ul><li>From Cancún: $175-250/person (longer travel)</p><ul><li>Duration: 6-8 hours total</p><ul><li>Book 1-2 weeks ahead in peak season</p><p>---</p><p><strong>La Paz (Sea of Cortez):</strong></p><p>La Paz offers whale shark encounters in calmer, more intimate conditions during winter months.</p><p><strong>Season:</strong> October - April <strong>Peak:</strong> November - February <strong>Setting:</strong> Bay near La Paz <strong>Advantage:</strong> Fewer crowds than Holbox, calmer water</p><p><strong>The Experience:</strong></p><ul><li>Smaller groups typical</p><ul><li>Shallower, calmer water</p><ul><li>Often juvenile whale sharks (still huge)</p><ul><li>Combine with sea lion snorkeling</p><p><strong>Tour Details:</strong></p><ul><li>Cost: $100-150/person</p><ul><li>Duration: 4-5 hours</p><ul><li>Book a few days ahead usually sufficient}

Other Whale Species

{<strong>Blue Whales:</strong></p><p>The largest animals ever to exist occasionally visit the Sea of Cortez.</p><p><strong>Location:</strong> Sea of Cortez, near Loreto <strong>Season:</strong> February - March <strong>Sightings:</strong> Uncommon but possible <strong>Tours:</strong> Multi-day expeditions best <strong>Experience:</strong> Seeing a 100-foot blue whale is extraordinary</p><p>---</p><p><strong>Orcas (Killer Whales):</strong></p><p>Orcas hunt in the Sea of Cortez, following sea lion colonies and other prey.</p><p><strong>Location:</strong> Sea of Cortez (Bahía de los Ángeles, Loreto) <strong>Season:</strong> May - June (sporadic) <strong>Sightings:</strong> Rare and unpredictable <strong>Tours:</strong> Not specifically offered; bonus on other trips</p><p>---</p><p><strong>Sperm Whales:</strong></p><p>Deep-diving sperm whales inhabit offshore waters.</p><p><strong>Location:</strong> Deep waters off Pacific coast <strong>Season:</strong> Year-round (sporadic) <strong>Sightings:</strong> Rare; specialized trips required</p><p>---</p><p><strong>Fin Whales:</strong></p><p>The second-largest whale species feeds in the Sea of Cortez.</p><p><strong>Location:</strong> Sea of Cortez <strong>Season:</strong> February - April <strong>Sightings:</strong> Occasional on whale watching trips</p><p>---</p><p><strong>Bryde's Whales:</strong></p><p>Tropical whales that remain year-round in warm Mexican waters.</p><p><strong>Location:</strong> Both Pacific and Caribbean coasts <strong>Season:</strong> Year-round <strong>Sightings:</strong> Common on boat trips}

Best Locations Ranked

{<strong>For Gray Whales:</strong></p><p>1. <strong>Laguna San Ignacio</strong> - Most intimate, famous for friendly encounters</p><ol><li><strong>Ojo de Liebre</strong> - Most accessible, highest numbers</p><ol><li><strong>Bahía Magdalena</strong> - Good experience, less crowded</p><p><strong>For Humpbacks:</strong></p><p>1. <strong>Puerto Vallarta / Banderas Bay</strong> - Highest concentration, closest approaches</p><ol><li><strong>Los Cabos</strong> - Dramatic scenery, combine with other activities</p><ol><li><strong>Mazatlán</strong> - Less touristy, good sightings</p><p><strong>For Whale Sharks:</strong></p><p>1. <strong>Holbox</strong> - Largest aggregation, peak summer</p><ol><li><strong>La Paz</strong> - Calmer conditions, winter season</p><ol><li><strong>Cabo Pulmo</strong> - Occasional encounters while diving</p><p><strong>Best Multi-Species Destination:</strong></p><p><strong>La Paz / Sea of Cortez</strong> offers the most diverse whale watching:</p><ul><li>Whale sharks (Oct-Apr)</p><ul><li>Gray whales nearby (Jan-Mar)</p><ul><li>Blue whales (Feb-Mar)</p><ul><li>Dolphins year-round</p><ul><li>Sea lions year-round</p><p>Consider a 5-7 day La Paz trip in February for maximum variety.}

Planning Your Trip

{<strong>Gray Whale Trip Planning:</strong></p><p><strong>Option 1: Day Trip from Guerrero Negro</strong></p><ul><li>Fly to Loreto or drive Baja Highway 1</p><ul><li>Stay overnight in Guerrero Negro</p><ul><li>Morning whale watching tour</p><ul><li>Return same day or continue Baja trip</p><ul><li>Best for: Road trippers, time-limited visitors</p><p><strong>Option 2: Lagoon Camp Experience</strong></p><ul><li>Fly into Loreto or La Paz</p><ul><li>Transfer to lagoon camp (San Ignacio)</p><ul><li>2-3 nights in basic but comfortable camps</p><ul><li>Multiple whale excursions included</p><ul><li>Best for: Dedicated whale lovers, photographers</p><p><strong>Recommended Operators:</strong></p><ul><li>Baja Expeditions</p><ul><li>Kuyimá Eco-Tourism</p><ul><li>Pachico's Tours (San Ignacio)</p><ul><li>Malarrimo Tours (Guerrero Negro)</p><p>---</p><p><strong>Humpback Whale Trip Planning:</strong></p><p><strong>Puerto Vallarta:</strong></p><ul><li>Stay in PV, Sayulita, or Punta Mita</p><ul><li>Book morning tour (calmer water)</p><ul><li>Half-day activity; combine with other plans</p><ul><li>Many operators; book through hotel or direct</p><p><strong>Los Cabos:</strong></p><ul><li>Tours depart Cabo San Lucas marina</p><ul><li>Often combined with El Arco boat trip</p><ul><li>Shorter tours (2-3 hours) available</p><ul><li>Resort concierge books easily</p><p>---</p><p><strong>Whale Shark Trip Planning:</strong></p><p><strong>Holbox:</strong></p><ul><li>Fly to Cancún, transfer to Chiquilá, ferry to Holbox</p><ul><li>Stay on Holbox 2-3 nights</p><ul><li>Book tour 1-2 weeks ahead</p><ul><li>June-September only</p><p><strong>La Paz:</strong></p><ul><li>Fly to La Paz directly or drive from Los Cabos</p><ul><li>Stay in La Paz 2-3 nights</p><ul><li>October-April season</p><ul><li>Combine with Espíritu Santo Island}

What to Expect on Tours

{<strong>Gray Whale Tours:</strong></p><p><strong>Logistics:</strong></p><ul><li>Small boats (pangas): 6-10 passengers</p><ul><li>Life jackets provided</p><ul><li>2-4 hours on water</p><ul><li>Multiple whale encounters typical</p><ul><li>Touching possible but not guaranteed</p><p><strong>What to Bring:</strong></p><ul><li>Layers (mornings cold, midday warm)</p><ul><li>Sunscreen and hat</p><ul><li>Waterproof camera</p><ul><li>Motion sickness meds if prone</p><ul><li>Binoculars (helpful, not essential)</p><p>---</p><p><strong>Humpback Tours:</strong></p><p><strong>Logistics:</strong></p><ul><li>Larger boats typically (12-40 passengers)</p><ul><li>Covered and open seating</p><ul><li>3-4 hours duration</p><ul><li>Distance varies; can be close approaches</p><ul><li>Breaching not guaranteed but common</p><p><strong>What to Bring:</strong></p><ul><li>Camera with zoom lens</p><ul><li>Sunscreen and hat</p><ul><li>Layers (ocean cooler than shore)</p><ul><li>Motion sickness prevention</p><p>---</p><p><strong>Whale Shark Tours:</strong></p><p><strong>Logistics:</strong></p><ul><li>Snorkel gear provided</p><ul><li>Two snorkelers + guide in water at a time</p><ul><li>Multiple rotations/encounters</p><ul><li>Water is warm (no wetsuit needed)</p><ul><li>Fins required (usually provided)</p><p><strong>What to Bring:</strong></p><ul><li>Swimsuit</p><ul><li>Reef-safe sunscreen</p><ul><li>Underwater camera (GoPro ideal)</p><ul><li>Towel and change of clothes</p><ul><li>Snacks/water</p><p><strong>Physical Requirement:</strong> You must be comfortable swimming in open water. Life jackets available for less confident swimmers.}

Responsible Whale Watching

{<strong>Ethical Guidelines:</strong></p><p><strong>For All Whale Encounters:</strong></p><ul><li>Use licensed operators only</p><ul><li>Respect distance regulations</p><ul><li>Don't chase or surround animals</p><ul><li>Never touch (unless whale initiates)</p><ul><li>Follow guide instructions</p><ul><li>Don't use flash photography</p><p><strong>Gray Whale Specifics:</strong></p><ul><li>Mexican law regulates boat numbers in lagoons</p><ul><li>Whales choose to approach; never forced</p><ul><li>Boats must idle when whales nearby</p><ul><li>Time limits in proximity enforced</p><p><strong>Whale Shark Specifics:</strong></p><ul><li>Holbox has strict regulations (not always followed)</p><ul><li>Only 2 people + guide in water at a time</p><ul><li>No touching (fines possible)</p><ul><li>No flash photography</p><ul><li>Minimum distance: 2 meters</p><ul><li>Choose operators who follow rules</p><p><strong>Choosing Ethical Operators:</strong></p><p><strong>Green Flags:</strong></p><ul><li>Certified/licensed by SEMARNAT</p><ul><li>Follows distance guidelines</p><ul><li>Educates about conservation</p><ul><li>Limits group sizes</p><ul><li>Doesn't guarantee touching</p><p><strong>Red Flags:</strong></p><ul><li>Promises guaranteed contact</p><ul><li>Overcrowded boats</p><ul><li>Chases animals aggressively</p><ul><li>Ignores approach limits</p><ul><li>No environmental briefing}

Photography Tips

{<strong>Camera Gear:</strong></p><p><strong>Gray Whales:</strong></p><ul><li>Whales come close—wide angle useful</p><ul><li>Waterproof camera or housing essential (spray)</p><ul><li>24-70mm zoom versatile</p><ul><li>Fast shutter speed for action</p><ul><li>Burst mode for breaches</p><p><strong>Humpbacks:</strong></p><ul><li>Telephoto lens important (100-400mm)</p><ul><li>Stabilization helps on boats</p><ul><li>Fast shutter (1/1000+ for breaches)</p><ul><li>Continuous autofocus</p><ul><li>Shoot horizontal for breaches</p><p><strong>Whale Sharks:</strong></p><ul><li>GoPro or underwater camera</p><ul><li>Wide angle essential (animals are huge)</p><ul><li>Video mode often better than stills</p><ul><li>No flash allowed</p><ul><li>Dome port helps with half-underwater shots</p><p><strong>General Tips:</strong></p><p>- Protect gear from salt spray</p><ul><li>Bring lens cloth (you'll need it)</p><ul><li>Waterproof bag for transport</p><ul><li>Backup battery (cold/wet drains fast)</p><ul><li>Download images daily (salt corrosion risk)</p><p><strong>Smartphone Options:</strong></p><ul><li>Waterproof case essential</p><ul><li>Works well for gray whales (close)</p><ul><li>Limited for humpbacks (distance)</p><ul><li>GoPro better for whale sharks}

Combining with Other Activities

{<strong>Gray Whales + Baja Road Trip:</strong></p><ul><li>Day 1-2: Valle de Guadalupe wine country</p><ul><li>Day 3-4: Drive to Guerrero Negro, whale watching</p><ul><li>Day 5-6: Continue to Loreto, Sea of Cortez</p><ul><li>Day 7-8: La Paz, whale sharks or Espíritu Santo</p><ul><li>Day 9-10: Los Cabos, fly home</p><p><strong>Humpbacks + Puerto Vallarta:</strong></p><ul><li>Morning whale watching</p><ul><li>Afternoon beach time</p><ul><li>Day trip to Sayulita</p><ul><li>Marietas Islands snorkeling</p><ul><li>Tequila tasting</p><ul><li>Jungle zip-lining</p><p><strong>Humpbacks + Los Cabos:</strong></p><ul><li>Morning whale watching</p><ul><li>El Arco visit (same trip often)</p><ul><li>Afternoon golf or spa</p><ul><li>Sunset sailing</p><ul><li>Desert excursions</p><ul><li>Cabo Pulmo snorkeling</p><p><strong>Whale Sharks + Holbox:</strong></p><ul><li>Whale shark morning</p><ul><li>Afternoon beach time</p><ul><li>Bioluminescence tour (night)</p><ul><li>Day trip to Isla Pájaros</p><ul><li>Kiteboarding</p><ul><li>Flamingo spotting (Río Lagartos nearby)</p><p><strong>Whale Sharks + La Paz:</strong></p><ul><li>Morning whale sharks</p><ul><li>Espíritu Santo Island day</p><ul><li>Sea lion snorkeling</p><ul><li>Malecón sunset walks</p><ul><li>Day trip to Todos Santos</p><ul><li>Diving at Cabo Pulmo}

Frequently Asked Questions

Can you really touch gray whales?

Yes—but only when they approach you. Gray whales in Baja's lagoons frequently swim to boats and surface beside them, sometimes allowing (seemingly inviting) gentle touches. This is wild animal behavior you cannot force; ethical operators let whales make the choice. When it happens, it's extraordinary.

Is swimming with whale sharks safe?

Completely safe. Whale sharks are filter feeders eating only plankton—they have no interest in humans as food. Their mouths are large but their throats are small. The main caution is avoiding accidental contact with their powerful tail. Follow your guide's instructions and maintain distance.

What if I get seasick?

Take motion sickness medication (Dramamine, Bonine) 30-60 minutes before departure. Ginger supplements help some people. Choose calm-water options when possible (lagoons are calmer than open ocean). Sit near the center of the boat, look at the horizon, and avoid strong smells.

Which experience is best for families with kids?

Gray whales in Baja work well for ages 6+ (boat rides aren't too long, close encounters thrill kids). Whale sharks require swimming ability and comfort in open water—better for teens. Humpback watching works for all ages but younger kids may lose patience during searching periods.

What if we don't see any whales?

During peak season with reputable operators, this is rare but possible. Gray whale lagoon trips almost always produce encounters. Humpback trips occasionally come up empty (10-15% chance at peak). Whale shark trips depend on animal movements—reputable operators refund or rebook if no sightings.
